etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in William Thomas (d. 1554), scholar, administrator, and alleged traitor. Originally from Italian bardassa, †bardasso, (now chiefly regional) bardascia; further etymology uncertain

definitions: A boy or young man who is made use of as a (typically passive) sexual partner by an older man. More generally: a (younger) passive partner in homosexual anal intercourse. Often used contemptuously, sometimes as a more general term of abuse.
